SC has no Governance plans
By ALVIN STEIN
The Governance issue at
Hopkins, which has been the
subject of years of study and
debate, is virtually defunct.
The problem of adequate
governance at Homewood, was
first considered in the summer of
1970, by a University formed
committee consisting of faculty
and students.
A referendum of
undergraduates, graduate
students, and faculty taken in the
fall of 1970 concerning the
report of this committee, was
rejected by the undergraduates.
The major reason for rejection of
the proposal was cited as the lack
of policy -making power
delegated to the undergraduates
under this report.
Two Plans
Revisions on the formal 60
page governance report issued by
this committee, were made by
the student council governance
committee formed last year,.
under the direction of Chris

Ohly. Two governance plans were
formulated, Plan A and Plan B.
Plan A proposed a University
senate consisting of faculty,
non -tenured faculty,
undergraduates, graduate
students, and the Dean of
Students which was to be the
policy making body of the
University Homewood Campus.
Plan B stated that this
particular group would not make
policy, but that they would act
in reviewing additions by the
Dean, and could also function as
having a veto power over
administrative decisions.
At registration last January, a
vote was taken by students as to
which plan was preferred. Of the
600 students who participated in
the voting, the majority favored
Plan B.
After the acceptance of Plan B
by the student body, the
proposal was submitted to the
Faculty General Assembly for
approval. According to S.C.
President, Andy Savitz, "This

plan has not yet been considered
by the Assembly."
Smitz stated that "unless there
is a strong demand from students
to work on governance, the
Student Council won't touch it
this year." He added, "students
were hopped up about
governance because the
credibility of the Council was at
a nadir last year."
"The Student Council plans to
touch on governance only if
students see a direct need for
investigation into this area,"
stated Savitz.
Commenting on the idea of a
University Senate to consider
governance problems, Savitz
stated, "the idea of such-a body
is impractical, as there are not
that many problems of major
importance to be considered by
such a large committee."
In conclusion, Savitz added,
"the more power the Student
Council can gain, the less need
we will have for governance
considerations."

from politics. When they let the

this tragedy."

blown far out of proportion, and

intended. Like any Olympic

page governance report issued by

the student council governance

senate consisting of faculty,
non -tenured faculty,
undergraduates, graduate
students, and the Dean of
Students which was to be the
policy making body of the
University Homewood Campus.
Plan B stated that this
particular group would not make
policy, but that they would act
in reviewing additions by the
Dean, and could also function as
having a veto power over
administrative decisions.

vote was taken by students as to
which plan was preferred. Of the
600 students who participated in

Plan B.

proposal was submitted to the
Faculty General Assembly for

Booter season starts Saturday
By CHUCK SLONIM
The Hopkins soccer team
picked up 3 pre-season victories
at the end of last week which
boosts their pre-season record to
4 wins and 1 loss with only one
more scrimmage to go before
their first game of the season
against Haverford this Saturday.
On Thursday, the team from
Archbishop Curley High School
came to Homewood as the Jays
planned to make up for
Tuesday's loss against Calvert
Hall High School. Hopkins pretty
much outclassed Curley, but
couldn't get the ball to do what

they wanted it to do.
Marc Manzione placed the first
goal well away from the Curley
goalie's hands on an assist from
Robert Arguero in the first half.
Curley retaliated and within 5
minutes broke through the Blue
Jay defense to tie the score.
The game was at a stalemate
through the remainder of the
first half and through most of the
second half when in the last 1 o
minutes of the game, the Blue
Jays started to put their skills
together. Arguero headed the ball
with less than a minute to go to
win the game 2-1.

Friday's game with the
Community College of Baltimore
saw outstanding performances by
freshman Bruce Cavenzas and
junior Robert Arguero. Arguero
had two goals, the first coming in
the first half when his initial
attempt to head the ball into the
goal was deflected by the CCB
goalie back to ARguero who
again headed it over the goalie
and into the net. Cavenzas scored
the first goal of his collegiate
career in the second half and, on
his assist, Arguero put in the
winning goal in the final minutes
of play.
On Saturday the Blue Jay
soccer alumni returned to give
this year's team a run for their
money. The alumni scored first
off the toe of last year's Scot
Tyner. This, for the most part,
satisfied the somewhat out-ofshape stars ofyesteryear, though,
in the second half, they were able
to slip two more into the net.
Arguero had 2 goals, and
"Tebby" Theibert had his first
goal of this season along with
Phil Hieter to give the younger
Blue Jays a 4-3 victory over their
predecessors.

Olympics come under questioning
The 1972 Olympic Games
have recently concluded in
Munich with a renewed pledge to
continue the Olympic ideals four
years from now.
However, to millions of
distressed observers the world
over, those ideals and, more
specifically, the merits of the
Games themselves have come
into serious question.
What eme4rged from the
spectacle 'in Munich was not the
notion of "the best athletes in
the world vying against one
another in the true spirit of
friendly competition," but rather
a lingering cloud of bitter
nationalism, politics and most
regrettably, sheer horror.
It is too convenient and naive,
however, to blame this sudden
loss of faith on the senseless
tragedy of September 5th which
left 17 dead. Although the horror
of that attack is surely not to be

discounted or diminished, its
cause lies far too deep to be
dismissed as an isolated folly of a
handful of madmen.
The politically-motivated
exclusion of Rhodesia from what
purports to be an athletic
competition was the initial step
in dooming the 1972 Games tc
failure. As U.S. discus thrower
Jay Silvester lamented, "The
Olympics must remain aloof
from politics. When they let the
Rhodesians get thrown out, they
were perpetrating something like
this tragedy."
The Olympics have been
blown far out of proportion, and
consequently, hardly serve the
purposes that their creators
intended. Like any Olympic
Games, these had their moments
of brilliance --the amazing feats
of swimmer Mark Spitz, the
infectious grace and beauty of
gymnast Olga Korbut, Shane

Gould and her toy kangeroo--but
these were far overshadowed by
the pettiness, chauvinism and
chicanery which prevailed almost
from the outset--culminating in
the still incomprehensible
U.S.-Russia basketball "game".
The unfortunate moments of
tilt Twentieth Olympiad are too
numerous and unpleasant to
mention, however, the following
incident, which went virtually
unnoticed, bears repeating as a
sorrowful reminder of what the
Olympics have become: Jim
McKay's frenzied explanation
that the raised fingers of the
victorious U.S. 400-meter relay
team signified, "We're Number
One!" and were not intended as a
political gesture of any kind.
Such assurances were sadly
necessary.
In the near future, Congress
will be asked to appropriate
$15.5 million for the Winter

Olympics in Denver. Whether or
not they will is uncertain, but
what is certain is that the Games
must either be diminished in
importance and put into
perspective, or simplY
discontinued.
The administrators and
organizers of the Olympics have
lost touch with athletes, athletics
and the realities of the world. If
they are to be continued, let the
Games be seen for what they
really are: a sporting event, a
pageant of friendly international
athletic competition, and not a
forum and showcase for
murderers, protesters, and
patriots.
With a feeling of great relief,
the Olympic Games have ended
with a vow to reconvene in 1976.
For many--the memory of
Munich still fresh in their
minds--the only solace is that
Montreal is still four years away.
